article:
2023 Canadian Wildfires

The 2023 Canadian wildfires were a series of devastating wildfires that swept across Canada, particularly in the western and central regions, during the spring and summer of 2023. The wildfires had significant domestic and international impacts, causing widespread evacuations, damage to infrastructure, and loss of life.

# Background

Canada is prone to wildfires due to its vast wilderness areas, dry climate, and lightning strikes. The country has experienced several major wildfires in recent years, including the 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire and the 2017 British Columbia wildfires. However, the 2023 wildfires were particularly severe, with many experts attributing the increased frequency and intensity of wildfires to climate change.

# Wildfires

The 2023 Canadian wildfires occurred in several provinces and territories, including Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Northwest Territories, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Quebec, and Saskatchewan.

## Alberta

Alberta was one of the hardest-hit provinces, with several major wildfires burning throughout the summer.

### High Level Forest Area

The High Level Forest Area wildfire was one of the largest and most destructive wildfires in Alberta, burning over 100,000 hectares of land. The fire forced the evacuation of several communities, including the town of High Level, and destroyed numerous homes and businesses.

## British Columbia

British Columbia also experienced several major wildfires, particularly in the southern and central regions of the province.

## Manitoba

Manitoba had several smaller wildfires, but they still caused significant disruptions and evacuations.

## New Brunswick

New Brunswick had a few small wildfires, but they were quickly brought under control.

## Newfoundland and Labrador

Newfoundland and Labrador had several small wildfires, particularly in the western region of the province.

## Northwest Territories

The Northwest Territories had several major wildfires, particularly in the southern region.

## Nova Scotia

Nova Scotia had several small wildfires, but they still caused significant disruptions.

### Barrington Lake wildfire

The Barrington Lake wildfire was one of the largest in Nova Scotia, burning over 1,000 hectares of land.

### Tantallon wildfire

The Tantallon wildfire was another significant fire in Nova Scotia, burning over 500 hectares of land.

## Ontario

Ontario had several small wildfires, particularly in the northern region of the province.

## Quebec

Quebec had several small wildfires, particularly in the western region of the province.

## Saskatchewan

Saskatchewan had several major wildfires, particularly in the central and southern regions.

# Domestic Impacts

The 2023 Canadian wildfires had significant domestic impacts, including evacuations, damage to infrastructure, and loss of life.

## Evacuations

Many communities were forced to evacuate due to the wildfires, with some people forced to flee their homes multiple times.

### Alberta evacuations

Over 10,000 people were evacuated in Alberta, with many forced to flee their homes in the High Level Forest Area.

### British Columbia evacuations

Over 5,000 people were evacuated in British Columbia, with many forced to flee their homes in the southern and central regions.

### Manitoba evacuations

Over 1,000 people were evacuated in Manitoba, with many forced to flee their homes in the southern region.

### Northwest Territories evacuations

Over 500 people were evacuated in the Northwest Territories, with many forced to flee their homes in the southern region.

### Nova Scotia evacuations

Over 500 people were evacuated in Nova Scotia, with many forced to flee their homes in the southern region.

### Quebec evacuations

Over 500 people were evacuated in Quebec, with many forced to flee their homes in the western region.

### Saskatchewan evacuations

Over 1,000 people were evacuated in Saskatchewan, with many forced to flee their homes in the central and southern regions.

## Other domestic impacts

The wildfires also had significant economic and political impacts.

### Economic

The wildfires caused significant damage to infrastructure, including homes, businesses, and roads. Many communities also experienced disruptions to essential services, including healthcare and education.

### Political

The wildfires led to calls for greater action on climate change and improved wildfire management. Many politicians also faced criticism for their handling of the crisis.

# International Effects

The 2023 Canadian wildfires also had significant international effects, including impacts on the environment and climate, as well as effects on neighboring countries.

## Effects on environment and climate

The wildfires released significant amounts of greenhouse gases, contributing to climate change. They also had impacts on local ecosystems, including the destruction of habitats and the loss of biodiversity.

## United States

The wildfires also had impacts on the United States, particularly in the states bordering Canada.

### May

In May, the US National Weather Service issued a red flag warning for several states, including Montana, Idaho, and Washington.

### June

In June, the US Forest Service reported that several wildfires were burning in the western states, including California, Oregon, and Wyoming.

## Europe

The wildfires also had impacts on Europe, particularly in the countries bordering the Arctic Circle.

# Fatalities

Unfortunately, the 2023 Canadian wildfires resulted in several fatalities, including firefighters and civilians.

# Domestic Government Responses

The Canadian government responded to the wildfires with a range of measures, including evacuations, firefighting efforts, and financial support.

## In Alberta

The Alberta government declared a state of emergency and deployed the military to assist with firefighting efforts.

## In British Columbia

The British Columbia government declared a state of emergency and deployed the military to assist with firefighting efforts.

## In Manitoba

The Manitoba government declared a state of emergency and deployed the military to assist with firefighting efforts.

## In the Northwest Territories

The Northwest Territories government declared a state of emergency and deployed the military to assist with firefighting efforts.

## In Nova Scotia

The Nova Scotia government declared a state of emergency and deployed the military to assist with firefighting efforts.

### Financial relief

The Nova Scotia government also provided financial support to affected communities, including funding for rebuilding and recovery efforts.

### Aftermath

The Nova Scotia government also established a review committee to examine the response to the wildfires and identify areas for improvement.

## In Saskatchewan

The Saskatchewan government declared a state of emergency and deployed the military to assist with firefighting efforts.

## Government strategies for future fires

The Canadian government has announced several strategies to prevent and respond to future wildfires, including increased funding for wildfire management and research into new technologies.

# Other Reactions

The 2023 Canadian wildfires also sparked a range of other reactions, including international responses and conspiracy theories.

## International responses

The international community responded to the wildfires with offers of support and assistance, including funding and personnel.

## Facebook blocking wildfire news stories

Facebook faced criticism for blocking news stories about the wildfires, with some users reporting that their posts were being removed or restricted.

## Conspiracy theories

article:
North Kosovo Crisis (2022–2024)

The North Kosovo Crisis, which began in July 2022 and is ongoing, is a period of heightened tensions and conflict between Kosovo and Serbia, centered in the north of Kosovo. The crisis has its roots in the complex history of the region, including the Kosovo War and the declaration of independence by Kosovo in 2008.

# Background

The Kosovo War, fought between 1998 and 1999, resulted in the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people, primarily ethnic Albanians. Following the war, Kosovo was administered by the United Nations, and in 2008, the Kosovo Assembly declared independence from Serbia. However, Serbia, along with several other countries, refused to recognize Kosovo's sovereignty. The north of Kosovo, where a majority of the population is ethnic Serb, has remained a point of contention.

In the years leading up to the crisis, relations between Kosovo and Serbia had been strained. Tensions were further exacerbated by the failure of EU-mediated talks aimed at normalizing relations between the two countries. The situation on the ground in north Kosovo was marked by a lack of trust between the local population and the government in Pristina, as well as limited access to basic services and infrastructure.

# Timeline

## 2022

### July

On July 10, 2022, Kosovo's government, led by Prime Minister Albin Kurti, announced plans to introduce new regulations requiring drivers with Serbian-issued license plates to replace them with Kosovo-issued plates. The move was intended to bring Kosovo's laws into line with those of other European countries and to reduce tensions with Serbia. However, the decision was met with widespread opposition from the ethnic Serb population in north Kosovo, who saw it as an attempt to assert Pristina's authority over the region.

### August

Tensions escalated in August, as Kosovo police attempted to implement the new regulations. On August 1, a group of ethnic Serb protesters blocked the main road connecting Kosovo to Serbia, sparking clashes with Kosovo police. The situation rapidly deteriorated, with reports of violence, including the use of tear gas and firearms.

### September

In September, the international community stepped in to try to mediate a resolution to the crisis. The EU's High Representative, Josep Borrell, traveled to the region, meeting with leaders from both Kosovo and Serbia. However, the talks failed to produce a breakthrough, and tensions remained high.

### October

On October 15, Kosovo's government announced plans to establish a new municipality in north Kosovo, which would be administered by the central government. The move was seen as an attempt to assert Pristina's authority over the region, and it was met with widespread opposition from the ethnic Serb population.

### November

In November, the situation on the ground in north Kosovo continued to deteriorate. There were reports of violence, including the use of explosives and firearms, and several people were injured. The international community continued to call for calm, but the situation remained volatile.

### December

As the year drew to a close, the crisis in north Kosovo showed no signs of abating. The ethnic Serb population continued to protest against the government's plans, and tensions remained high. The international community continued to mediate, but a resolution to the crisis remained elusive.

## 2023

### January

In January 2023, the EU's High Representative, Josep Borrell, returned to the region, meeting with leaders from both Kosovo and Serbia. The talks were seen as a last-ditch effort to resolve the crisis, but they ultimately failed to produce a breakthrough.

### February

The move was seen as an attempt to assert Pristina's authority over the region, and it was met with widespread opposition from the ethnic Serb population.

### March

### May

article:
Battle of Bakhmut

The Battle of Bakhmut was a prolonged and intense military conflict between Ukrainian forces and Russian forces, with support from the Wagner Group, a Russian private military company, in and around the city of Bakhmut, Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine. The battle began in August 2022 and lasted until early June 2023, making it one of the longest and bloodiest battles of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.

#Background

The city of Bakhmut, with a pre-war population of around 70,000, is a strategic location in the Donetsk Oblast, lying about 45 kilometers northeast of the regional capital, Donetsk. The city's proximity to the front lines and its position on the main road connecting Donetsk to Luhansk and the Russian border made it an important military objective for both sides. The battle for Bakhmut was part of the larger Donbas campaign, which began in April 2022, and aimed to capture the entire Donetsk and Luhansk regions.

#Battle

##Early shelling and Russian encroachment (August–October 2022)

The battle for Bakhmut began in August 2022, when Russian forces, with support from the Wagner Group, started shelling the city and its surroundings. The initial goal was to weaken Ukrainian defenses and create a breach in the front lines. Ukrainian forces responded with artillery fire, and both sides engaged in a series of skirmishes and reconnaissance missions. Despite the intensity of the fighting, neither side made significant gains, and the front lines remained relatively stable.

##Early winter escalation (November–December 2022)

As winter approached, the fighting around Bakhmut intensified, with both sides launching a series of attacks and counterattacks. Russian forces attempted to break through Ukrainian defenses, but their advances were repeatedly repelled. Ukrainian forces, meanwhile, launched a series of local counterattacks, aimed at pushing the Russians back and relieving pressure on the city. The fighting was characterized by heavy artillery exchanges, with both sides suffering significant casualties.

##Capture of Soledar and partial encirclement (January–April 2023)

In January 2023, Russian forces captured the nearby town of Soledar, which lies about 15 kilometers northeast of Bakhmut. The fall of Soledar allowed Russian forces to partially encircle Bakhmut, cutting off one of the main supply routes to the city. Ukrainian forces responded by launching a series of counterattacks, aimed at retaking Soledar and relieving pressure on Bakhmut. Despite initial gains, Ukrainian forces were ultimately unable to retake the town.

##Ukrainian flanking counterattacks begin (May 2023)

In May 2023, Ukrainian forces launched a series of flanking counterattacks, aimed at outmaneuvering Russian forces and relieving pressure on Bakhmut. The counterattacks were launched from the north and northwest, with Ukrainian forces making significant gains and pushing the Russians back. The success of the counterattacks created a new threat to Russian positions, and forced them to divert troops from other parts of the front.

##Capture of Bakhmut and Wagner withdrawal (20 May–early June 2023)

On 20 May 2023, Russian forces, with support from the Wagner Group, captured the city of Bakhmut. The fall of the city was the result of a prolonged and intense battle, which had lasted for over nine months. Following the capture of the city, Wagner forces began to withdraw from the area, handing control over to regular Russian troops. The withdrawal was seen as a significant development, as it marked the first time that Wagner forces had been involved in a major battle and then withdrawn.

#Military strength and tactics

The military strength and tactics employed by both sides during the battle for Bakhmut varied significantly. Ukrainian forces relied heavily on artillery and infantry, with a focus on defensive operations. Russian forces, meanwhile, employed a range of tactics, including artillery bombardments, infantry assaults, and the use of Wagner Group mercenaries. The use of Wagner forces allowed Russian commanders to deploy troops in a more flexible and adaptable manner, and to take greater risks on the battlefield.

#Aftermath

##Strategic value

The capture of Bakhmut was seen as a significant strategic victory for Russian forces, as it gave them control of a key road junction and allowed them to threaten Ukrainian positions in the Donetsk Oblast. However, the victory came at a high cost, with both sides suffering significant casualties. The city itself was largely destroyed, and the surrounding area was heavily contaminated with unexploded ordnance.

##Battlefield conditions

The battlefield conditions around Bakhmut were characterized by heavy destruction and contamination. The city itself was largely reduced to rubble, with many buildings destroyed or badly damaged. The surrounding area was heavily mined, with both sides laying extensive networks of landmines and booby traps. The use of artillery and other heavy weapons created a significant risk of unexploded ordnance, which posed a threat to both military personnel and civilians.

##Casualties

The exact number of military casualties suffered during the battle for Bakhmut is unknown, but it is estimated that both sides suffered significant losses. The civilian population of Bakhmut suffered heavily during the battle, with many residents forced to flee the city or take shelter in basements and other underground areas. The battle for Bakhmut was characterized by significant attrition on both sides. Norway at the 2022 Winter Olympics

The 2022 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXIV Olympic Winter Games, were held in Beijing, China, from February 4 to 20, 2022. Norway sent a team of 84 athletes to compete in 9 sports. The Norwegian team was one of the largest and most successful teams at the Games.

# Medalists

Norway won a total of 37 medals, including 16 gold medals, 8 silver medals, and 13 bronze medals. The country finished second in the overall medal table, behind Germany. The most successful Norwegian athletes were Marte Olsbu Røiseland and Johannes Thingnes Bø, who each won 5 medals in biathlon.

# Competitors

A total of 84 athletes represented Norway at the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team consisted of 44 men and 40 women, competing in 9 sports. The Norwegian team was led by chef de mission, Tore Øvrebø.

# Alpine Skiing

Norway sent a team of 11 alpine skiers to the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team included Olympic medalists, Henrik Kristoffersen and Sebastian Foss-Solevåg. The best result for Norway in alpine skiing came in the men's slalom, where Sebastian Foss-Solevåg won the silver medal.

# Biathlon

Norway's biathlon team was one of the most successful teams at the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team consisted of 12 athletes, including Olympic medalists, Marte Olsbu Røiseland and Johannes Thingnes Bø. Marte Olsbu Røiseland won 5 medals, including 3 gold medals, while Johannes Thingnes Bø won 5 medals, including 3 gold medals. The Norwegian team won a total of 10 medals in biathlon, including 5 gold medals.

# Cross-Country Skiing

Norway sent a team of 20 cross-country skiers to the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team included Olympic medalists, Therese Johaug and Simen Hegstad Krüger. The best result for Norway in cross-country skiing came in the women's 10km classic, where Therese Johaug won the gold medal.

# Curling

## Men's Tournament

Norway's men's curling team finished fifth in the round-robin stage, with a record of 4 wins and 5 losses. The team was eliminated in the semifinals, losing to Great Britain.

## Mixed Doubles Tournament

Norway's mixed doubles curling team finished fourth in the round-robin stage, with a record of 6 wins and 2 losses. The team was eliminated in the semifinals, losing to Italy.

# Freestyle Skiing

Norway sent a team of 4 freestyle skiers to the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team included Olympic medalist, Sandra Näslund. The best result for Norway in freestyle skiing came in the women's ski cross, where Sandra Näslund finished fourth.

# Nordic Combined

Norway's nordic combined team finished second in the team event, behind Germany. The team consisted of 5 athletes, including Olympic medalist, Jarl Magnus Riiber.

# Ski Jumping

Norway sent a team of 7 ski jumpers to the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team included Olympic medalist, Robert Johansson. The best result for Norway in ski jumping came in the men's normal hill individual, where Robert Johansson finished fourth.

# Snowboarding

Norway sent a team of 4 snowboarders to the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team included Olympic medalist, Ståle Sandbech. The best result for Norway in snowboarding came in the men's slopestyle, where Ståle Sandbech finished fifth.

# Speed Skating

Norway sent a team of 8 speed skaters to the 2022 Winter Olympics. The team included Olympic medalist, Håvard Holmefjord Lorentzen. The best result for Norway in speed skating came in the men's 1000m, where Håvard Holmefjord Lorentzen won the silver medal.

article:
Angela Lansbury

Angela Lansbury is a British-American actress, singer, and producer whose career has spanned over seven decades. Born on October 16, 1925, in Regent's Park, London, Lansbury has established herself as a highly accomplished and versatile performer, with numerous awards and accolades to her name. This article provides an overview of her life, career, and achievements.

#Early life and career beginnings

##Childhood: 1925–1942

Angela Lansbury was born to Edgar Lansbury, a timber merchant, and Moyna MacGill, an Irish actress. She was the first of two daughters, with her younger sister, Isolde, being born in 1929. The family moved to the United States in 1940, settling in New York City. Lansbury's early life was marked by a love for the performing arts, with her mother encouraging her to pursue a career in acting.

##Career breakthrough: 1942–1945

Lansbury's breakthrough role came in 1942, when she was cast as Nancy Olivier in the film Gaslight. Her performance earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress, making her one of the youngest nominees at the time. This success led to a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), where she went on to appear in a string of films, including National Velvet (1944) and The Picture of Dorian Gray (1945).

##Later MGM films: 1945–1951

During her time at MGM, Lansbury appeared in a range of films, including The Harvey Girls (1946), The Three Musketeers (1948), and The Red Danube (1949). While these films were not always critically acclaimed, they helped establish Lansbury as a versatile and talented young actress.

#Mid career

##The Manchurian Candidate and minor roles: 1952–1965

In the early 1950s, Lansbury began to appear in more substantial roles, including the critically acclaimed film The Manchurian Candidate (1962). However, she also found herself typecast in minor roles, often playing the part of the "older woman" or "matronly figure." Despite this, Lansbury continued to work steadily in film and television, appearing in productions such as The Long, Hot Summer (1958) and The Alfred Hitchcock Hour (1962).

##Mame and theatrical stardom: 1966–1969

Lansbury's theatrical career gained momentum in the mid-1960s, with her starring role in the Broadway musical Mame (1966). Her performance as the titular character earned her a Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical, cementing her status as a leading lady of the stage. Lansbury went on to appear in a string of successful Broadway productions, including Dear World (1969) and Prettybelle (1971).

##Ireland and Gypsy: 1970–1978

In the early 1970s, Lansbury moved to Ireland, where she lived for several years. During this time, she continued to work in film and theater, appearing in productions such as Gypsy (1974) and The Last of Mrs. Cheyney (1977). Lansbury's performance in Gypsy earned her a second Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical.

##Sweeney Todd and continued cinematic work: 1979–1984

Lansbury's theatrical career continued to thrive in the late 1970s and early 1980s, with her starring role in the Broadway musical Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (1979). Her performance as Nellie Lovett earned her a third Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical. Lansbury also continued to work in film, appearing in productions such as The Mirror Crack'd (1980) and The Company of Wolves (1984).

#Global fame

##Murder, She Wrote: 1984–2003

Lansbury's most iconic role came in 1984, when she was cast as mystery writer Jessica Fletcher in the television series Murder, She Wrote. The show became a global phenomenon, running for 12 seasons and earning Lansbury numerous awards and nominations, including 12 Emmy Award nominations for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series.

##Final years: 2003–2022

After the conclusion of Murder, She Wrote, Lansbury continued to work in film and television, appearing in productions such as Nanny McPhee (2005) and Mary Poppins Returns (2018). She also continued to work in theater, appearing in productions such as A Little Night Music (2009) and Blithe Spirit (2014).

#Personal life

Angela Lansbury has been married twice, first to actor Richard Cromwell in 1945, and then to actor Peter Shaw in 1949. She has two children, Anthony Shaw and Deidre Shaw, both from her second marriage. Lansbury has been open about her struggles with addiction and depression, using her platform to raise awareness and support for mental health causes.

#Honours and legacy

Throughout her career, Lansbury has received numerous awards and accolades, including six Tony Awards, six Golden Globe Awards, and 12 Emmy Award nominations. She has also been recognized for her philanthropic work, particularly in the area of mental health awareness. In 2013, Lansbury was appointed a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire (DBE) by Queen Elizabeth II.

#Publications

2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup

The 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup was the sixth edition of the Asian Men's Volleyball Cup, a biennial international volleyball tournament organized by the Asian Volleyball Confederation (AVC). The tournament was held in Pasig, Philippines, from August 7 to 14, 2022.

# Host selection

The Philippines was awarded the hosting rights for the 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup by the AVC in 2020. This marked the second time the country hosted the tournament, after the 2018 edition.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup consisted of two rounds: the zonal round and the final round. In the zonal round, teams were divided into six zones: Central Asia, East Asia, Oceania, Southeast Asia, South Asia, and West Asia. Each zone held a separate tournament, with the top two teams from each zone advancing to the final round.

## Qualified teams

A total of 11 teams qualified for the 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup. The teams were:

* Australia
* China

* India
* Iran
* Japan
* Kazakhstan
* Qatar
* South Korea
* Thailand
* Uzbekistan

# Venues

The 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup was held at the PhilSports Arena in Pasig, Philippines. The arena has a seating capacity of 5,000 spectators.

article:
Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt, also known as the Hessian State Museum Darmstadt, is a museum located in Darmstadt, Germany. The museum is one of the largest and most important cultural institutions in the state of Hesse, showcasing a wide range of collections and exhibitions that highlight the art, history, and culture of the region.

# History

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt was founded in 1820 as the "Grossherzogliches Museum" (Grand Ducal Museum) by Grand Duke Ludwig I of Hesse. The museum's initial collection consisted of artworks and artifacts from the grand ducal family's private collections, as well as donations from local artists and collectors. Over the years, the museum's collections grew significantly, and by the late 19th century, it had become one of the leading cultural institutions in the region.

In the early 20th century, the museum underwent significant changes, including a major renovation and expansion of its building. The museum's collections were also reorganized and expanded to include a wider range of art and cultural artifacts. During World War II, the museum suffered significant damage, and many of its collections were lost or destroyed. In the post-war period, the museum underwent a major rebuilding and restoration effort, which restored it to its former glory.

# Building

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt is located in a historic building in the heart of Darmstadt's old town. The building was originally constructed in the 19th century as a grand ducal palace, and it features a stunning example of neoclassical architecture.

## Location

The museum is situated on Friedensplatz, a major public square in the center of Darmstadt. The square is surrounded by several other important cultural institutions, including the Darmstadt State Theater and the Darmstadt City Museum.

## Renovations and extensions

Over the years, the museum's building has undergone several major renovations and extensions. In the early 20th century, the building was expanded to include several new galleries and exhibition spaces. In the 1960s, the museum underwent a major modernization effort, which included the installation of new heating and cooling systems, as well as the creation of new exhibition spaces.

In the 1990s, the museum underwent a major restoration effort, which restored the building's historic facade and interior spaces. The restoration effort included the reconstruction of the building's original grand staircase, as well as the restoration of several historic galleries and exhibition spaces.

# Collections

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has a wide range of collections that showcase the art, history, and culture of the region. The museum's collections include:

* A significant collection of European art, including works by artists such as Rembrandt, Rubens, and Dürer
* A large collection of artifacts and artworks from the grand ducal family's private collections
* A collection of cultural and historical artifacts from the region, including archaeological finds, furniture, and decorative arts
* A collection of prints and drawings, including works by artists such as Picasso and Matisse
* A collection of modern and contemporary art, including works by artists such as Warhol and Pollock

# Gallery

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has several permanent galleries that showcase the museum's collections. The galleries include:

* The Grand Ducal Gallery, which features a selection of artworks from the grand ducal family's private collections
* The European Art Gallery, which features a selection of European art from the 15th to the 20th centuries
* The Regional History Gallery, which features a selection of cultural and historical artifacts from the region
* The Modern and Contemporary Art Gallery, which features a selection of modern and contemporary art

# Special exhibitions

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt also hosts several special exhibitions throughout the year. The exhibitions are typically organized around a specific theme or topic, and they feature artworks and artifacts from the museum's collections, as well as loans from other museums and institutions.

Some recent special exhibitions at the museum have included:

* An exhibition on the art and culture of the grand ducal family
* An exhibition on the history of the region, featuring archaeological finds and cultural artifacts
* An exhibition on modern and contemporary art, featuring works by local and international artists

# Controversies

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has been involved in several controversies over the years, including disputes over the ownership and provenance of certain artworks and artifacts. In the 1990s, the museum was involved in a major controversy surrounding the ownership of a collection of artworks that had been looted by the Nazis during World War II.

In recent years, the museum has also been involved in debates surrounding the display and interpretation of certain artworks and artifacts, including works that are considered to be culturally sensitive or historically problematic.

Alexander Suvorov

Alexander Vasilyevich Suvorov was a renowned Russian military leader, renowned for his exceptional leadership and tactical genius. Born on November 24, 1729, in Moscow, Russia, he rose to prominence during the reign of Catherine the Great and went on to become one of the most celebrated military minds in Russian history.

#Early life

##Origins

Alexander Suvorov was born into a noble family, with his father, Vasily Ivanovich Suvorov, serving as a senator and his mother, Avdotya Fyodorovna Mansurova, being a member of the nobility. His family was of Russian and Swedish ancestry, with his great-grandfather, Ivan Suvorov, having immigrated to Russia from Sweden in the 17th century.

##Childhood

Little is known about Suvorov's early childhood, but it is believed that he spent most of his youth in Moscow, where he received a traditional noble education. He demonstrated exceptional intelligence and aptitude for mathematics and languages from an early age. Suvorov's family moved to St. Petersburg in 1742, where he continued his education and began to develop an interest in military affairs.

#Early career

##First military experience

Suvorov's first military experience came in 1748, when he joined the Russian army as a cadet in the Semenovsky Regiment. He quickly distinguished himself as a talented and dedicated young officer, rising through the ranks to become a lieutenant by 1754.

##1761

In 1761, Suvorov was appointed as a captain in the Izmailovsky Regiment and saw action in the Seven Years' War against Prussia. He demonstrated exceptional bravery and tactical acumen during the war, earning the respect of his superiors and the admiration of his peers.

##Freemasonry, Berlin

During his time in Berlin, Suvorov became acquainted with the principles of Freemasonry, which had a profound impact on his worldview and approach to leadership. He saw the fraternity as a way to promote unity and cooperation among nations and to foster personal growth and self-improvement.

#Wars against Poland–Lithuania

The war was marked by a series of setbacks and defeats for the Russian army, but Suvorov's tactical genius and bravery helped to turn the tide of the conflict.

###Retaliatory strike

In 1769, Suvorov led a successful retaliatory strike against the Polish-Lithuanian forces, capturing the strategic fortress of Krakow and forcing the rebels to retreat. This victory marked a turning point in the war and earned Suvorov widespread recognition and acclaim.

In 1794, Suvorov was appointed as the commander of the Russian army in Poland and led a series of successful campaigns against the Polish uprising. He won several decisive victories, including the Battle of Maciejowice and the Battle of Praga, which crushed the rebellion and secured Russian control over Poland.

article:
Jane Birkin

Jane Birkin is a British actress and singer who has been active in the entertainment industry for over five decades. Born on December 14, 1946, in Marylebone, London, England, Birkin has established herself as a talented and versatile performer, known for her distinctive voice, striking features, and eclectic film choices.

#Early life

Jane Birkin was born to David Birkin, a Royal Navy lieutenant commander, and Judy Campbell, an actress. Her maternal grandparents were also actors, and her great-aunt was the actress and comedian, Hermione Gingold. Birkin's family moved to Chelsea, London, where she spent most of her childhood. She was educated at Upper Chine School, a private school in Isle of Wight, and later attended the École Jeannine Manuel in Paris, where she developed her French language skills.

#Career

##Early acting credits

Birkin began her acting career in the 1960s, appearing in small roles in British films and television productions. Her breakthrough came in 1966 with the film "The Knack... and How to Get It," directed by Richard Lester, where she played the role of a fashion model. The film's success led to more prominent roles in films like "Blow-Up" (1966), directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, and "Wonderwall" (1968), directed by Joe Massot.

##Collaborations with Serge Gainsbourg

In the late 1960s, Birkin met French singer-songwriter Serge Gainsbourg, with whom she began a romantic relationship. The couple collaborated on several musical projects, including the hit single "Je T'aime... Moi Non Plus" (1969), which became a chart-topping success in several countries. The song's explicit lyrics and Birkin's breathy vocals caused controversy, but it remains one of the most iconic duets of all time. Birkin and Gainsbourg continued to work together on music and film projects, including the albums "Di Doo Dah" (1973) and "Lolita Go Home" (1975).

##Later performances and recordings

After her collaborations with Gainsbourg, Birkin continued to act in films and television productions, appearing in a wide range of genres, from drama to comedy. She released several solo albums, including "Baby Alone in Babylone" (1983) and "Lost Song" (1987), and worked with various musicians, such as Bryan Ferry and Tom Waits. In the 1990s, Birkin began to focus more on her music career, releasing the album "Versions Jane" (1996), which featured her interpretations of songs by artists like Gainsbourg and Édith Piaf.

#Personal life

##Death

Serge Gainsbourg passed away on March 2, 1991, due to complications from a heart attack. Birkin was devastated by his death and has since spoken publicly about the impact of his passing on her life and career.

##Philanthropy

Birkin has been involved in various charitable causes throughout her career, including Amnesty International and the French organization, "Les Restos du Cœur," which provides food and support to homeless people. In 2011, she was appointed as a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).

##Political views and activism

Birkin has been an outspoken advocate for human rights and social justice, often using her platform to raise awareness about various causes. In 2015, she was involved in a controversy surrounding the Birkin bag, a luxury handbag made by Hermès, which was named after her. Birkin asked Hermès to remove her name from the bag, citing concerns about the treatment of crocodiles used to make the bag's leather.

#Awards and honours

Throughout her career, Birkin has received numerous awards and honors for her contributions to film, music, and philanthropy. In 1985, she was awarded the National Order of Merit by the French government, and in 1992, she received the César Award for Best Actress for her performance in the film "A Soldier's Tale."

#In popular culture

##Birkin basket

In the 1970s, Birkin became a style icon, and her image was often featured in fashion magazines and newspapers. The "Birkin basket," a wicker basket bag, became a popular fashion accessory, named after her signature style.

##Birkin bag

The Birkin bag, designed by Hermès in the 1980s, is one of the most iconic and luxurious handbags in the world. The bag's design and craftsmanship have made it a status symbol, and it is often associated with wealth and exclusivity.

title: Mount_Omurga
article:
Mount Omurga

Mount Omurga is a mountain peak located in the Crimean Mountains, on the Crimean Peninsula, Ukraine. It is one of the highest peaks in the range and offers breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape.

# Geography
Mount Omurga is situated in the central part of the Crimean Mountains, approximately 30 kilometers southwest of the city of Simferopol. The mountain is part of the Babugan Yayla, a mountain plateau that stretches for over 10 kilometers. The peak of Mount Omurga has an elevation of 1,541 meters above sea level, making it one of the highest points in the Crimean Mountains.

## Location and Climate
Mount Omurga is located in a region with a humid continental climate, characterized by warm summers and cold winters. The average temperature in the area ranges from 4°C in January (the coldest month) to 22°C in July (the warmest month). The mountain is surrounded by forests of beech, oak, and pine trees, which provide a habitat for a variety of flora and fauna.

# Geology
Mount Omurga is composed primarily of limestone and dolomite rocks, which date back to the Jurassic period. The mountain is also home to several caves and rock formations, including the famous "Devil's Bridge" (Chertova Mostka), a natural rock bridge that spans a deep gorge.

## Tectonic Activity
The Crimean Mountains, including Mount Omurga, are located in a seismically active region. The mountain range was formed as a result of tectonic activity, which pushed the Earth's crust upwards to create the mountain peaks. The region is still subject to periodic earthquakes, which can cause rockfalls and landslides on the mountain slopes.

# Ecology
Mount Omurga is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna, including several endemic species that are found only in the Crimean Mountains. The mountain forests provide a habitat for a variety of animals, including deer, wild boar, and eagles.

## Vegetation
The vegetation on Mount Omurga is characterized by a mix of broadleaf and coniferous forests. The lower slopes of the mountain are covered in deciduous forests of beech, oak, and hornbeam trees, while the higher slopes are dominated by coniferous forests of pine and spruce trees. The mountain is also home to several rare and endangered plant species, including the Crimean edelweiss and the Crimean bellflower.

## Wildlife
Mount Omurga is home to a variety of wildlife, including several species of mammals, birds, and reptiles. The mountain forests provide a habitat for a variety of animals, including deer, wild boar, and eagles. The mountain is also home to several rare and endangered species, including the Crimean ibex and the European lynx.

# History
Mount Omurga has a rich cultural and historical heritage, with evidence of human habitation dating back to the ancient Greeks. The mountain was an important center of worship for the ancient Greeks, who built a temple to the god Apollo on the mountain peak.

## Ancient History
The ancient Greeks established a settlement on the mountain, which they called "Temple of Apollo". The temple was built on the mountain peak and was an important center of worship for the ancient Greeks. The temple was later destroyed by the Romans, who built a new temple on the site.

## Medieval History
During the Middle Ages, Mount Omurga was an important center of trade and commerce. The mountain was a key stopping point for merchants traveling between the Black Sea and the Mediterranean Sea. The mountain was also an important center of learning, with several monasteries and convents established on the mountain slopes.

## Modern History
In the 19th century, Mount Omurga was a popular destination for tourists, who came to the mountain to enjoy the scenic views and the healthy climate. The mountain was also an important center of scientific research, with several scientists and explorers visiting the mountain to study the geology and ecology of the area.

# Tourism
Mount Omurga is a popular destination for tourists, who come to the mountain to enjoy the scenic views, the healthy climate, and the rich cultural and historical heritage. The mountain offers several hiking trails, including the popular "Omurga Trail", which takes hikers to the mountain peak.

## Hiking and Climbing
Mount Omurga offers several hiking trails, including the popular "Omurga Trail", which takes hikers to the mountain peak. The mountain is also a popular destination for rock climbers, who come to the mountain to climb the steep rock faces.

## Accommodation and Infrastructure
There are several hotels and guesthouses on the mountain, which offer accommodation and meals to tourists. The mountain also has several restaurants and cafes, which serve traditional Crimean cuisine. The mountain is accessible by car, with several roads leading to the mountain peak.

# Conservation
Mount Omurga is a protected area, with several nature reserves and national parks established on the mountain slopes. The mountain is home to several rare and endangered species, including the Crimean ibex and the European lynx.

## Protected Areas
There are several protected areas on Mount Omurga, including the "Crimean Nature Reserve" and the "Babugan Yayla National Park". These protected areas provide a habitat for a variety of flora and fauna, including several rare and endangered species.

## Conservation Efforts
There are several conservation efforts underway on Mount Omurga, including the protection of rare and endangered species, the restoration of habitats, and the promotion of sustainable tourism. The mountain is also home to several research centers, which study the geology, ecology, and biology of the area.

Armorial of Albania

The Armorial of Albania is a collection of coats of arms used by the nobility, feudal lords, and other prominent figures in Albania throughout its history. Heraldry in Albania has its roots in the medieval period, and over time, it has been influenced by various cultures and empires that have ruled the region.

# Medieval period

## Ambiguitatem

During the medieval period, Albania was a part of the Byzantine Empire, and as such, it was influenced by Byzantine heraldry. The use of coats of arms was not widespread, and it was mainly limited to the nobility and high-ranking clergy. One of the earliest known examples of Albanian heraldry is the coat of arms of the Ambiguitatem family, which dates back to the 12th century. The Ambiguitatem family was a noble family that played an important role in the medieval history of Albania.

## Regnum Albaniæ

In the 13th century, Albania became a kingdom under the rule of the Angevin dynasty. During this period, the use of coats of arms became more widespread, and the kingdom's nobility adopted their own coats of arms. The Regnum Albaniæ, or the Kingdom of Albania, had its own coat of arms, which featured a double-headed eagle, a symbol that would later become a common feature of Albanian heraldry.

## Feudal lords

During the medieval period, Albania was divided into several feudal lordships, each with its own coat of arms. The feudal lords, such as the Thopia, Muzaka, and Dukagjini families, played an important role in the medieval history of Albania, and their coats of arms are still remembered today. The coats of arms of these feudal lords often featured symbols of their power and authority, such as eagles, lions, and dragons.

# Albanian nobility

## Austria-Hungary

In the 19th century, Albania became a part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, and as such, it was influenced by Austro-Hungarian heraldry. Many Albanian nobles adopted Austro-Hungarian-style coats of arms, which featured symbols of their loyalty to the empire. The coats of arms of the Albanian nobility during this period often featured the double-headed eagle, a symbol of the Austrian Empire.

## Italian States

### La Serenìssima

During the 18th and 19th centuries, parts of Albania were under the rule of the Venetian Republic, also known as La Serenìssima. The Venetian Republic had its own system of heraldry, and many Albanian nobles adopted Venetian-style coats of arms. The coats of arms of the Albanian nobility during this period often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Venetian Republic, such as the winged lion of St. Mark.

#### Albania Vèneta

Albania Vèneta was a province of the Venetian Republic that included parts of modern-day Albania. The province had its own coat of arms, which featured a winged lion of St. Mark. Many Albanian nobles from this region adopted Venetian-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Venetian Republic.

#### Dalmatia

Dalmatia was a province of the Venetian Republic that included parts of modern-day Croatia and Albania. The province had its own coat of arms, which featured a shield with three stripes. Many Albanian nobles from this region adopted Venetian-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Venetian Republic.

#### Istria

Istria was a province of the Venetian Republic that included parts of modern-day Croatia, Slovenia, and Italy. The province had its own coat of arms, which featured a shield with a diagonal stripe. Many Albanian nobles from this region adopted Venetian-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Venetian Republic.

### Dicio Pontificia

Dicio Pontificia was a province of the Papal States that included parts of modern-day Albania. The province had its own coat of arms, which featured a shield with a cross. Many Albanian nobles from this region adopted Papal-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Papal States.

### Genoa, Neapolis, Sicilia...

Genoa, Neapolis, and Sicilia were all Italian states that had colonies or territories in Albania during the medieval period. Many Albanian nobles from these regions adopted Italian-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Italian states.

## Moldavia & Romania

In the 19th century, parts of Albania were under the rule of Moldavia and Romania. Many Albanian nobles from these regions adopted Moldavian and Romanian-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Moldavian and Romanian principalities.

## Greece

In the 19th century, parts of Albania were under the rule of Greece. Many Albanian nobles from these regions adopted Greek-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Greek kingdom.

## Ottoman Empire

### Grand viziers

The Ottoman Empire ruled Albania for nearly 500 years, and as such, it had a significant influence on Albanian heraldry. Many Albanian nobles adopted Ottoman-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Ottoman Empire. The grand viziers, or prime ministers, of the Ottoman Empire had their own coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their power and authority.

## Egypt

In the 19th century, parts of Albania were under the rule of Egypt. Many Albanian nobles from these regions adopted Egyptian-style coats of arms, which often featured symbols of their loyalty to the Egyptian khedivate.

# Modern period

In the 20th century, Albania became an independent state, and as such, it adopted its own national coat of arms. The national coat of arms features a double-headed eagle, a symbol that dates back to the medieval period. Many Albanian families and institutions have adopted their own coats of arms, which often feature symbols of their history and heritage.

# Ecclesiastical coats of arms

## Coats of arms

The Albanian Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Church in Albania have their own coats of arms, which feature symbols of their faith and authority. Many Albanian bishops and clergy have their own coats of arms, which often feature symbols of their office and jurisdiction.

## Seals

The Albanian Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Church in Albania have their own seals, which feature symbols of their faith and authority. Many Albanian bishops and clergy have their own seals, which often feature symbols of their office and jurisdiction.

# In society

Heraldry plays an important role in Albanian society, and many families and institutions have adopted their own coats of arms. The use of coats of arms is not limited to the nobility, and many ordinary people have adopted their own coats of arms as a symbol of their heritage and identity.

article:
Ole Miss Riot of 1962

The Ole Miss Riot of 1962 was a violent confrontation between federal authorities and protesters at the University of Mississippi (also known as Ole Miss) in Oxford, Mississippi, on September 30, 1962. The incident occurred when James Meredith, a 29-year-old African American veteran, attempted to enroll at the university, which had previously been segregated. The event was a pivotal moment in the American Civil Rights Movement and marked a significant turning point in the struggle for racial equality in the United States.

# Leadup

## Meredith's attempts to enroll

James Meredith, a native of Kosciusko, Mississippi, had served in the United States Air Force and had been inspired by the Civil Rights Movement while stationed in Japan. After his discharge, he applied to the University of Mississippi, which had a long history of segregation. Despite meeting the university's admission requirements, Meredith's application was rejected, citing a lack of space and his failure to provide adequate recommendations. Meredith, with the assistance of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), filed a lawsuit against the university, arguing that the rejection was racially motivated.

## Kennedy dialogue and escalating tensions

In the months leading up to Meredith's enrollment, tensions between the federal government and the state of Mississippi escalated. President John F. Kennedy and his brother, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, engaged in a series of telephone conversations with Mississippi Governor Ross Barnett, urging him to comply with the court's ruling and allow Meredith to enroll. However, Barnett refused, citing the state's sovereignty and the need to maintain segregation. The Kennedy brothers eventually obtained a federal court order requiring the university to admit Meredith, but Barnett continued to resist, calling on Mississippians to protest the federal government's actions.

# Events

## Meredith arrives

On September 30, 1962, James Meredith arrived at the University of Mississippi's Lyceum building, accompanied by federal marshals and a small group of supporters. As they attempted to enter the building, a crowd of protesters, including students, local residents, and state officials, blocked their path. The protesters, many of whom were armed, began to chant and shout, and the situation quickly escalated.

## Violence on campus

As the protesters clashed with the federal marshals, violence erupted on campus. Rocks, bricks, and bottles were thrown, and several people were injured. The marshals, who were not authorized to use firearms, attempted to disperse the crowd using tear gas and batons. However, the protesters continued to resist, and the situation spiraled out of control. At one point, a group of protesters attempted to set fire to a federal marshal's car, and several buildings on campus were vandalized.

## Military response

As the violence continued to escalate, President Kennedy deployed federal troops to the university to restore order. At 8:00 p.m., a convoy of military vehicles arrived on campus, and soldiers from the 2nd Infantry Division and the 101st Airborne Division began to disperse the crowd. The soldiers, who were armed with rifles and bayonets, used tear gas and batons to clear the area, and the protesters slowly began to retreat.

## Aftermath

In the aftermath of the riot, two people were killed, and over 300 were injured. James Meredith, who had been forced to take cover during the violence, was eventually escorted to his dormitory, where he spent the night under the protection of federal marshals. The next day, he attended his first classes at the university, marking a significant milestone in the Civil Rights Movement.

# Legacy

The Ole Miss Riot of 1962 marked a turning point in the Civil Rights Movement, as it highlighted the need for federal intervention to enforce desegregation in the South. The event also marked a significant shift in the Kennedy administration's approach to civil rights, as the president began to take a more active role in promoting racial equality. The riot also had a lasting impact on the University of Mississippi, which eventually became a symbol of progress and reconciliation in the South.

In 2006, the University of Mississippi dedicated a statue to James Meredith, commemorating his bravery and perseverance in the face of violence and intimidation. The statue, which is located near the Lyceum building, serves as a reminder of the university's complex history and its ongoing commitment to diversity and inclusion.

# Notes and references

## Notes

This article is a comprehensive account of the Ole Miss Riot of 1962, drawing on a range of historical sources and scholarly research.

article:
Speak Now (Taylor's Version)
==========================

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) is the re-recorded version of American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift's third studio album, Speak Now (2010). The re-recorded album was released on July 7, 2023, through Republic Records.

Background
---------

In June 2019, it was announced that Scooter Braun's company, Ithaca Holdings, had acquired Big Machine Records, Swift's former record label, for $300 million. As a result, Braun's company acquired the rights to Swift's master recordings from her first six studio albums, including Speak Now. Swift publicly expressed her disapproval of the deal, stating that she had not been given the opportunity to purchase her master recordings herself and that Braun's ownership of her music was a "worst-case scenario" for her.

In August 2020, Swift announced that she would be re-recording her first six studio albums in an effort to regain control over her master recordings. She stated that she would be re-recording the albums "in order to regain control of my master recordings" and that she would be releasing new versions of her songs "in the hopes that [fans] will listen to the re-recorded versions instead of the old master recordings".

Music and lyrics
-----------------

The re-recorded album features the same track listing as the original album, with the addition of six "From the Vault" tracks that were written and recorded during the same time period as the original album.

### Composition

The re-recorded album features a mix of country, pop, and rock influences, with many of the songs featuring acoustic instrumentation and introspective lyrics. The album's sound is characterized by Swift's distinctive vocals and songwriting style, which often focuses on themes of love, heartbreak, and self-empowerment.

### "From the Vault" tracks

The six "From the Vault" tracks on the re-recorded album were written and recorded during the same time period as the original album, but were not included on the final track listing. The tracks include "You All Over Me", "Mr. Perfectly Fine", "We Were Happy", "That's When", "Don't You", and "Bye Bye Baby".

Release
--------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) was released on July 7, 2023, through Republic Records. The album was made available on CD, digital download, and streaming platforms.

Critical reception
-----------------

The re-recorded album received widespread critical acclaim upon its release. Many critics praised Swift's vocals and songwriting, as well as the album's production and nostalgic value.

Commercial performance
--------------------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart, with sales of over 200,000 copies in its first week. The album also reached number one on the UK Albums Chart and the Australian Albums Chart.

Recognition
------------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) was recognized by several publications as one of the best albums of 2023.

article:
Kokshetau
================

Kokshetau is a city located in northern Kazakhstan, serving as the administrative center of Akmola Region. With a rich history dating back to the 19th century, Kokshetau has evolved into a significant cultural, economic, and educational hub in the region.

Names and Etymology
--------------------

### Chronology of name changes

The city has undergone several name changes throughout its history. Initially, it was known as Kokchetav, derived from the Kazakh words "kok" meaning "blue" and "chetav" meaning "hill". In 1993, the city's name was officially changed to Kokshetau, which is the Kazakh pronunciation of the original name.

Physical Geography and Geology
------------------------------

### Location

Kokshetau is situated in the northern part of Kazakhstan, approximately 300 kilometers northwest of the capital city Astana. The city lies in the Kokchetav Depression, surrounded by the Kokchetav Mountains to the east and the Ishim River to the west.

### Time

Kokshetau is located in the Eastern European Time (EET) zone, which is 2 hours ahead of Coordinated Universal Time (UTC+2).

### Climate

The city experiences a humid continental climate, with cold winters and warm summers. The average temperature in January, the coldest month, is around -15°C, while the average temperature in July, the warmest month, is around 20°C. Annual precipitation is around 300 mm, with most of it falling during the summer months.

Legal Status and Administrative-Territorial Division
---------------------------------------------------

### Administrative districts and microdistricts

Kokshetau is divided into three administrative districts: Kokchetav, Zarechny, and Severny. The city also has several microdistricts, including Aktobe, Almaty, and Astana.

### Districts

The city is further divided into several districts, including the Old Town, which is the historic center of Kokshetau, and the New Town, which is a more recent development.

Authorities, Local Government, and Politics
-------------------------------------------

### Kokshetau authorities

The city is governed by the Akim (Mayor) of Kokshetau, who is appointed by the President of Kazakhstan. The Akim is responsible for implementing national policies and making decisions on local issues.

### Regional authorities

The Akmola Region, where Kokshetau is located, is governed by the Akim of the region, who is also appointed by the President of Kazakhstan.

#### List of akims (mayors) of Kokshetau (1992–present)

* Zhaksybekov, A. (1992-1995)
* Suleimenov, A. (1995-2001)
* Nigmatullin, R. (2001-2006)
* Kurmangaliyeva, G. (2006-2012)
* Zhaksybekov, A. (2012-2018)
* Absattarov, A. (2018-present)

#### Politics

Kokshetau is a stronghold of the Nur Otan party, which is the ruling party in Kazakhstan. The city has a relatively stable political environment, with little opposition to the government.

History
--------

### Early history

The area where Kokshetau is located today has been inhabited since ancient times. Archaeological findings have revealed evidence of human settlement dating back to the Bronze Age.

### Foundation of Kokshetau (1824–1917)

The city was founded in 1824 as a Russian fortification, known as Kokchetavskaya Krepost. The fort was established to protect the local population from raids by nomadic tribes. Over time, the fort grew into a small town, which became an important center of trade and commerce in the region.

### Soviet era (1918–1991)

During the Soviet era, Kokshetau underwent significant development, with the establishment of various industries, including textiles, food processing, and construction materials. The city also became an important center of education and culture, with the establishment of several universities and cultural institutions.

### Fall of the Soviet Union and modern history (1991–present)

Following the collapse of the Soviet Union, Kokshetau has continued to develop, with a focus on economic growth and modernization. The city has become an important center of trade and commerce, with a strong focus on export-oriented industries.

Demographics
------------

### Population

As of 2020, the population of Kokshetau is approximately 140,000 people.

### Languages

The official languages of Kokshetau are Kazakh and Russian, although many residents also speak other languages, including English and Turkish.

### Ethnic and national composition

The city has a diverse ethnic composition, with Kazakhs making up the majority of the population, followed by Russians, Ukrainians, and other ethnic groups.

### Religion

The majority of the population practices Islam, with the Sunni branch being the most prevalent.

#### Sunni Islam

The city has several mosques, including the Central Mosque, which is one of the largest in the country.

#### Russian Orthodox Church

The city also has a significant Russian Orthodox population, with several churches, including the Assumption Cathedral.

#### Other religions

The city also has smaller communities of other religions, including Catholics, Protestants, and Buddhists.

Entertainment, Tourism, and Culture
------------------------------------

### Theatres

Kokshetau has several theatres, including the Kokchetav Drama Theatre and the Akmola Regional Philharmonic.

### National events/festivals

The city hosts several national events and festivals, including the Kokchetav International Music Festival and the Akmola Regional Fair.

### Philharmonic

The Akmola Regional Philharmonic is a popular cultural institution, which hosts a variety of concerts and performances throughout the year.

### Historical museums

The city has several historical museums, including the Kokchetav Museum of Local History and the Akmola Regional Museum of History and Culture.

### Cinemas

Kokshetau has several cinemas, including the Shalkar Cinema and the Eurasia Cinema.

### Libraries

The city has several libraries, including the Akmola Regional Library and the Kokchetav City Library.

#### Public libraries

The city has several public libraries, which offer a wide range of books and other materials.

#### University libraries

The city's universities also have libraries, which offer a wide range of academic materials.

Kazakhstan Capital of Culture 2021
---------------------------------

Kokshetau was designated as the Kazakhstan Capital of Culture in 2021, in recognition of its rich cultural heritage and contributions to the country's cultural development.

Palaces

Mausoleums

Cemeteries

Monuments and Memorials

The city has a diverse economy, with a strong focus on industry, including textiles, food processing, and construction materials.

### Health and medical care

The city has several hospitals and medical facilities, including the Kokchetav City Hospital and the Akmola Regional Hospital.

The city has a well-developed telecommunications infrastructure, with several mobile phone operators and internet service providers.

The city has several newspapers and magazines, including the Kokchetav Gazeti and the Akmola Region Gazeti.

### TV and radio

The city has several TV and radio stations, including the Kokchetav TV and the Akmola Region Radio.

### Internet media

The city has several internet media outlets, including online news websites and social media platforms.

Transportation
----------------

The city has a well-developed public transportation system, including buses, taxis, and marshrutkas.

#### City buses

The city has an extensive network of city buses, which cover most areas of the city.

#### Public vans

The city also has a network of public vans, which operate on fixed routes.

The city has several taxi companies, which offer 24-hour service.

### Intercity transportation

The city is connected to other cities in Kazakhstan and beyond by road, rail, and air.

The city has a railway station, which offers regular services to other cities in Kazakhstan and Russia.

#### Intercity buses

The city has an intercity bus station, which offers regular services to other cities in Kazakhstan and beyond.

### Airport

The city has an airport, which offers regular flights to other cities in Kazakhstan and beyond.

### Road transportation and bridges

The city has a well-developed road network, with several bridges over the Ishim River.

Architecture and Landmarks
---------------------------

### Old Town

The city's Old Town is a historic area, with several preserved buildings from the 19th and early 20th centuries.

### Landmarks

The city has several landmarks, including the Kokchetav Monument to the Fallen Soldiers and the Akmola Regional Mausoleum.

#### Historical architecture

The city has several examples of historical architecture, including the Kokchetav Palace of Culture and the Akmola Regional Palace of Culture.

#### Soviet-era architecture

The city also has several examples of Soviet-era architecture, including the Kokchetav Cinema and the Akmola Region Hotel.

#### Contemporary architecture

The city has several examples of contemporary architecture, including the Kokchetav Business Center and the Akmola Region Shopping Center.

Education and Research
-------------------------

### Secondary, primary, and nursery

The city has several secondary, primary, and nursery schools, including the Kokchetav School No. 1 and the Akmola Region School No. 2.

### Colleges

The city has several colleges, including the Kokchetav College of Economics and the Akmola Region College of Technology.

### Institutions of higher education

The city has several institutions of higher education, including the Kokchetav State University and the Akmola Region State University.

#### National

The city has several national institutions of higher education, including the Kazakh National University and the Al-Farabi Kazakh National University.

#### Private

The city also has several private institutions of higher education, including the International University of Information Technologies and the Kazakh-British Technical University.

Sport
------

### Football

The city has a football team, Kokchetav FC, which competes in the Kazakhstan Premier League.

### Ice hockey

The city has an ice hockey team, Kokchetav HC, which competes in the Kazakhstan Hockey Championship.

### Basketball

The city has a basketball team, Kokchetav BC, which competes in the Kazakhstan Basketball Championship.

### Infrastructure

The city has several sports infrastructure facilities, including the Kokchetav Stadium and the Akmola Region Sports Complex.

### Clubs

The city has several sports clubs, including the Kokchetav Sports Club and the Akmola Region Sports Club.

Tourism and Shopping
---------------------

### Shopping and commerce

The city has several shopping centers, including the Kokchetav Shopping Center and the Akmola Region Shopping Center.

Parks and Recreation
---------------------

### Parks and gardens

The city has several parks and gardens, including the Kokchetav Park and the Akmola Region Garden.

#### Fountains

The city has several fountains, including the Kokchetav Fountain and the Akmola Region Fountain.

### Elikti

The city has a nature reserve, Elikti, which is home to several rare species of plants and animals.

### Recreation around Kokshetau

The city has several recreational areas around it, including the Kokchetav Lake and the Akmola Region Forest.

Significant Depictions in Art, Literature, and Popular Culture
-----------------------------------------------------------

Kokshetau has been depicted in several works of art, literature, and popular culture, including films, books, and songs.

International Relations
-------------------------

### Twin towns – Sister cities

Kokshetau has several twin towns and sister cities, including Wuxi, China, and Zielona Góra, Poland.

### Cooperation and friendship

The city has cooperation and friendship agreements with several cities around the world, including Tver, Russia, and Cherkasy, Ukraine.

Notable People
----------------

Kokshetau has been the birthplace or home of several notable people, including scientists, artists, and politicians.

article:
2022–23 Australian region cyclone season

The 2022–23 Australian region cyclone season was the period of the year when most tropical cyclones form in the southern Indian Ocean and southern Pacific Ocean, within the area bounded by 90°E and 160°E, south of the equator. The season officially ran from 1 November 2022 to 30 April 2023, although the first tropical low of the season formed on 26 October 2022.

# Season forecasts

Several national meteorological services and scientific agencies forecast how many tropical cyclones will form during a season and/or how many will reach tropical cyclone strength. These agencies include the Tropical Cyclone Warning Centres (TCWCs) in Perth, Darwin, and Brisbane, as well as the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA) in New Zealand. The forecasts generally predict the number of tropical cyclones that will form within the Australian region, and the number that will reach severe tropical cyclone strength.

On 27 October 2022, the BoM issued its tropical cyclone forecast for the coming season, predicting a near-average number of tropical cyclones would form in the Australian region during the 2022–23 season. The forecast also stated that there was a high chance of above-average tropical cyclone activity in the western and northwestern sub-regions.

# Season summary

The 2022–23 Australian region cyclone season was a near-average season, with a total of 22 tropical lows forming within the region. Of these, 11 reached tropical cyclone strength, and 5 reached severe tropical cyclone strength. The season officially started on 1 November 2022, and the first tropical low of the season formed on 26 October 2022. The last tropical low of the season dissipated on 27 April 2023.

The season saw several notable systems, including Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian, which formed in the Indian Ocean and moved southwards, eventually becoming a Category 5-equivalent cyclone on the SSHWS. Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy also formed in the Indian Ocean and moved westwards, eventually affecting the coast of Western Australia. Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle formed in the Coral Sea and moved southwards, eventually affecting the coast of New South Wales.

# Systems

## Tropical Cyclone 01U

Tropical Cyclone 01U was the first tropical low of the season, forming on 26 October 2022 in the Timor Sea. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching tropical cyclone strength on 28 October. The system reached its peak intensity on 30 October, with maximum sustained winds of 75 km/h (45 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 995 hPa. The system dissipated on 1 November.

## Tropical Low 02U

Tropical Low 02U formed on 5 November 2022 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly northwards, eventually reaching the coast of the Northern Territory on 7 November. The system dissipated on 8 November.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian

Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian formed on 16 November 2022 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly southwards, eventually reaching tropical cyclone strength on 18 November. The system reached its peak intensity on 21 November, with maximum sustained winds of 230 km/h (145 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 915 hPa. The system eventually moved out of the Australian region on 25 November.

## Tropical Cyclone Ellie

Tropical Cyclone Ellie formed on 25 November 2022 in the Timor Sea. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching the coast of Western Australia on 28 November. The system dissipated on 30 November.

## Tropical Low 07U (Hale)

Tropical Low 07U formed on 2 December 2022 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards, eventually reaching the coast of Queensland on 5 December. The system dissipated on 6 December.

## Tropical Low 10U

Tropical Low 10U formed on 15 December 2022 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly northwards, eventually reaching the coast of the Northern Territory on 17 December. The system dissipated on 18 December.

## Tropical Low 11U (Dingani)

Tropical Low 11U formed on 18 December 2022 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching the coast of Western Australia on 22 December. The system dissipated on 24 December.

## Tropical Low 12U

Tropical Low 12U formed on 25 December 2022 in the Timor Sea. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching the coast of Western Australia on 28 December. The system dissipated on 30 December.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy formed on 3 February 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching tropical cyclone strength on 5 February. The system reached its peak intensity on 7 February, with maximum sustained winds of 220 km/h (140 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 925 hPa. The system eventually moved out of the Australian region on 12 February.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle

Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle formed on 8 February 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards, eventually reaching tropical cyclone strength on 10 February. The system reached its peak intensity on 12 February, with maximum sustained winds of 200 km/h (125 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 935 hPa. The system eventually moved out of the Australian region on 16 February.

## Tropical Low 15U

Tropical Low 15U formed on 20 February 2023 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly northwards, eventually reaching the coast of the Northern Territory on 22 February. The system dissipated on 23 February.

## Tropical Low 16U

Tropical Low 16U formed on 25 February 2023 in the Timor Sea. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching the coast of Western Australia on 28 February. The system dissipated on 2 March.

## Tropical Low 17U

Tropical Low 17U formed on 3 March 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards, eventually reaching the coast of Queensland on 6 March. The system dissipated on 7 March.

## Tropical Low 18U (Kevin)

Tropical Low 18U formed on 9 March 2023 in the Indian Ocean. The system moved slowly westwards, eventually reaching the coast of Western Australia on 13 March. The system dissipated on 15 March.

## Tropical Low 20U

Tropical Low 20U formed on 20 March 2023 in the Arafura Sea. The system moved slowly northwards, eventually reaching the coast of the Northern Territory on 22 March. The system dissipated on 23 March.

## Severe Tropical Cyclone Herman

Severe Tropical Cyclone Herman formed on 25 March 2023 in the Coral Sea. The system moved slowly southwards, eventually reaching tropical cyclone strength on 27 March. The system reached its peak intensity on 30 March, with maximum sustained winds of 215 km/h (135 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 920 hPa. The system eventually moved out of the Australian region on 3 April.

## Tropical Low 22U
