article:
Tornado Outbreak of March 31 – April 1, 2023

The tornado outbreak of March 31 – April 1, 2023, was a significant weather event that affected several states in the central and southern United States, resulting in widespread destruction and loss of life. The outbreak occurred over a period of two days, with the majority of tornadoes touching down on the evening of March 31 and the morning of April 1.

# Meteorological Synopsis

The outbreak was caused by a strong low-pressure system that developed over the Rocky Mountains and moved eastward, bringing with it a cold front and a dry line. As the system interacted with a warm and moist air mass from the Gulf of Mexico, it created a highly unstable atmosphere that was conducive to thunderstorm development.

## March 31

On the evening of March 31, a strong squall line developed along the cold front, stretching from eastern Oklahoma to western Arkansas. As the squall line moved eastward, it produced numerous tornadoes, including several long-lived and intense tornadoes. The most significant tornado of the evening touched down in the Little Rock, Arkansas area, causing widespread destruction and loss of life.

## April 1

On the morning of April 1, the low-pressure system continued to move eastward, bringing the cold front and dry line into the Ohio Valley. As the system interacted with a warm and moist air mass from the Gulf of Mexico, it produced additional tornadoes, including several significant long-lived tornadoes. The most significant tornado of the morning touched down in the Ste. Marie, Illinois area, causing widespread destruction and loss of life.

# Confirmed Tornadoes

A total of 27 tornadoes were confirmed during the outbreak, including several long-lived and intense tornadoes.

## Little Rock–North Little Rock–Jacksonville, Arkansas

The first significant tornado of the outbreak touched down in the Little Rock, Arkansas area at approximately 7:00 PM CDT on March 31. The tornado, which was rated EF3, caused widespread destruction and loss of life as it moved through the city. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 20 miles, with maximum winds of up to 150 mph.

## Keota–Wellman, Iowa

A significant tornado touched down in the Keota, Iowa area at approximately 8:00 PM CDT on March 31. The tornado, which was rated EF2, caused significant damage as it moved through the city. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 15 miles, with maximum winds of up to 120 mph.

## Wynne–Parkin–Turrell, Arkansas/Drummonds–Burlison, Tennessee

A long-lived tornado touched down in the Wynne, Arkansas area at approximately 9:00 PM CDT on March 31. The tornado, which was rated EF3, moved eastward into Tennessee, causing significant damage and loss of life. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 50 miles, with maximum winds of up to 150 mph.

## Brighton–Covington–Brownsville, Tennessee

A significant tornado touched down in the Brighton, Tennessee area at approximately 10:00 PM CDT on March 31. The tornado, which was rated EF2, caused significant damage as it moved through the city. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 20 miles, with maximum winds of up to 120 mph.

## Ste. Marie–Robinson, Illinois/Merom–Sullivan, Indiana

A long-lived tornado touched down in the Ste. Marie, Illinois area at approximately 11:00 AM CDT on April 1. The tornado, which was rated EF3, moved eastward into Indiana, causing significant damage and loss of life. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 40 miles, with maximum winds of up to 150 mph.

## Bethel Springs–Adamsville–Hookers Bend–Hohenwald, Tennessee

A significant tornado touched down in the Bethel Springs, Tennessee area at approximately 12:00 PM CDT on April 1. The tornado, which was rated EF2, caused significant damage as it moved through the city. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 25 miles, with maximum winds of up to 120 mph.

# Non-Tornadic Effects

In addition to the tornadoes, the outbreak also produced significant non-tornadic effects, including heavy rain, hail, and strong winds.

## Tennessee

Heavy rain and hail caused significant damage in Tennessee, particularly in the western part of the state. Flash flooding was reported in several areas, with some areas receiving over 4 inches of rain.

## Blizzard

A blizzard warning was issued for several counties in the Ohio Valley, with heavy snowfall and high winds causing significant disruptions. Some areas received over 12 inches of snow, with drifts reaching up to 5 feet.

# Impact and Aftermath

The outbreak had a significant impact on the affected areas, with widespread destruction and loss of life. Emergency responders and aid organizations were deployed to the affected areas to provide assistance and support.

article:
Coronation of Mary I of England

The coronation of Mary I of England took place on 1 July 1553 at Westminster Abbey in London. Mary, also known as Mary Tudor or Bloody Mary, was the daughter of King Henry VIII and his first wife, Catherine of Aragon. She was a devout Catholic and sought to restore Catholicism in England, which had been largely abolished by her predecessor and half-brother, Edward VI.

# Proclamation on 19 July

Although Mary's coronation took place on 1 July, her accession to the throne was proclaimed on 19 July 1553. This was done to ensure a smooth transition of power and to legitimize her claim to the throne. The proclamation was made by the Lord Chancellor, Stephen Gardiner, who was a prominent Catholic and a strong supporter of Mary.

# The Oration gratulatory

As part of the coronation celebrations, an Oration gratulatory was delivered by the Bishop of Chichester, George Day. The oration was a formal speech that praised Mary's virtues and hailed her as the rightful queen of England. It was an important part of the coronation ritual, as it helped to establish Mary's legitimacy and authority.

# Plays and drama at the coronation

The coronation of Mary I was accompanied by various plays and dramatic performances. These performances were an integral part of the celebrations and helped to create a festive atmosphere. The plays were often allegorical and featured characters that symbolized virtues such as justice, mercy, and wisdom.

# Royal Entry to London

The royal entry to London was a grand procession that took place on the eve of the coronation. It was a traditional part of the coronation ritual, where the monarch would make a formal entry into the city.

## Coronation eve

On the eve of the coronation, Mary made her royal entry into London. She was accompanied by a large retinue of nobles, bishops, and other dignitaries. The procession was led by the Lord High Constable, who carried a white staff as a symbol of his office.

## The coronation entry

The coronation entry was a grand spectacle that featured elaborate pageants and decorations. The streets were lined with people, who cheered and waved as Mary passed by. The procession made its way to the Tower of London, where Mary would spend the night before the coronation.

# Coronation

The coronation of Mary I took place on 1 July 1553 at Westminster Abbey. It was a grand ceremony that was attended by many nobles and dignitaries.

## The mount and St Edward's chair

The coronation ceremony began with Mary's procession to the mount, a raised platform in the center of the abbey. She was accompanied by the Archbishop of York, who carried St Edward's chair, a sacred relic that was said to have been used in the coronation of Edward the Confessor.

## The traverse

After reaching the mount, Mary made her way to the traverse, a canopy that was carried by four knights. The traverse was a symbol of Mary's authority and power.

## Three crowns and two sceptres

Mary was crowned with three crowns, which symbolized her role as queen of England, France, and Ireland. She also received two sceptres, which represented her authority and power. The sceptres were carried by the Earls of Arundel and Shrewsbury.

# Banquet in Westminster Hall

After the coronation ceremony, a grand banquet was held in Westminster Hall. The banquet was attended by many nobles and dignitaries, who came to pay their respects to the new queen.

## The champion

The banquet was presided over by the champion, a ceremonial figure who was responsible for defending the queen's honor. The champion was a prominent nobleman who wore a suit of armor and carried a large wooden spoon.

## Proclamation

During the banquet, a proclamation was made by the Lord Chancellor, Stephen Gardiner. The proclamation hailed Mary as the rightful queen of England and praised her virtues.

# Costume

The coronation of Mary I was a grand spectacle that featured elaborate costumes and decorations.

## Blue and ray cloth

Mary wore a blue and ray cloth cloak, which was a symbol of her authority and power. The cloak was decorated with gold and precious stones.

## Anointing and a change of costume

During the coronation ceremony, Mary was anointed with holy oil by the Archbishop of York. After the anointing, she changed into a new costume, which was a symbol of her new role as queen.

## Gentlewomen and chamberers

Mary was attended by a retinue of gentlewomen and chamberers, who wore elaborate costumes and decorations. The gentlewomen and chamberers were responsible for attending to Mary's needs and carrying out various ceremonial duties.

## Reuse of coronation clothes by Elizabeth I

After Mary's death, her coronation clothes were reused by her half-sister, Elizabeth I. Elizabeth wore the same blue and ray cloth cloak that Mary had worn during her coronation. This was a symbol of Elizabeth's legitimacy and authority, as she sought to establish herself as the rightful queen of England.
